attributes.comment:
I am writing to request that you NOT raise the fees associated with adopting
foreign-born children. You will hear many reasons why this proposed increase is
unfair, most notably that fees are already unconscionably high especially given
the often long waits and sometimes poor service received, and especially given
the fact that prospective adoptive parents often must pay these fees twice or
even three times, when delays cause documents to expire and require refiling and
new filing fees.

All I wanted to add, as a psychologist, is that your handling of these issues
provides you with an opportunity to "win friends and influence people" at a time
when we are especially open to the support or lack thereof in fulfilling a
dream, to become parents of children desperately in need of families. A warm
welcome at the embassy when we are far from home and frightened that "something
could go wrong" at a last hurdle, is something we can remember for a lifetime as
our own government being "there for us" when it counted. Similarly, we may
remember the uncaring official, the unnecessary delay processing the initial
paperwork to start the I600A, and the sense that we are being "soaked" for high
fees under the mistaken assumption that if we have managed to afford to adopt
overseas, we must be wealthy families who will never miss a hundred dollars here
and a few hundred more there. Even more painful is the perhaps-paranoid,
perhaps realistic sense that we may be being punished for adopting overseas
instead of domestically, when we may well have been discriminated against and
denied by domestic agencies for years before opting to look internationally for
our kids.

Most native-born Americans never deal directly with USCIS and never have an
opportunity to form a personal opinion about your agency. Treating us fairly
and with sensitivity can go a long way to win our support for you as an agency,
or "leave a bad taste" forever ...

Thanks for considering this!
attributes.title: Comment Submitted by Elissa Schroeder
